author: Riath Al-Samarrai for the Daily Mail
title: Arsenal boss Wenger defends Ozil from 'blame culture'
text:
Arsene Wenger has hit out at the ‘blame culture’ that has seen Mesut Ozil singled out for criticism in Arsenal’s slump.
The German’s form has been called into question at times throughout the season and that has only intensified after an abject performance in the defeat at Chelsea last weekend.
There have been suggestions of disgruntlement among elements at the club that Ozil’s spot in the side is untouchable, but Wenger has gone to lengths this week to avoid singling out any players for the back-to-back losses that have all but killed Arsenal’s title hopes.
Arsene Wenger has hit out at the ‘blame culture’ that has seen Mesut Ozil criticised
The German’s form has been called into question at times throughout Arsenal's season
Wenger has gone to lengths this week to avoid singling out any players for back-to-back losses
The playmaker is expected to start when Arsenal face Hull and when asked if it was time for Ozil to shine, Wenger said: ‘The team wins and the team loses. When you win sometimes some players are singled out as they are treated like exceptional players but when you don’t do well sometimes focus should be a little bit more of the team aspect and not try to blame each other.
‘The blame culture is part of the perception of people, but what is important is that we show a united front.
‘We have a good opportunity to show that we are a united, strong unit and that we bounce back.
‘When you don’t win you cannot as well say that all is well. You have to analyse that something is not right. It is our job to find where and to have a strong united response.’
Wenger is said to be close to walking away from Arsenal amid fan protests after 20 years

It is understood an element of his thinking will be determined by public appetite for him to stay, which appears to be at a new low with this current league challenge fading away fast. His attempts to rally support this week included the suggestion that Arsenal’s fans ought to be more like those at Spurs, which amounted to a somewhat risky expression of a reasonable sentiment.
It never takes long for a drama to become a crisis among Arsenal’s support at this time of year, which therefore makes this clash with Hull all the more important after successive defeats. Ordinarily, it would appear a straightforward fixture, except Hull have been revived to some extent by Marco Silva’s arrival last month.
Wenger said: ‘He is doing well. There are many top managers in Europe and they all come to England.
‘I believe as well that they played well with Mike Phelan but so many times they were not rewarded by results and they had injuries as well. I think Hull always played good football.’
